reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's time to break a little bad.

Basement is a drug empire strategy game which is currently available through Steam Early Access. In Basement your aim is to create a successful drug empire by building facilities to produce drugs and taking over drug selling business to sell your product. But tread lightly, the larger your business grows the more attention you will attract from the police who will attempt to raid your facilities unless you 'persuade' them otherwise.

I'm not in the meth business. I'm in the empire business.

A word of warning, Basement, in its current stage, is more of a proof of concept than a game as most of the planned features are not present in the game yet. Despite the lack of content I, as a huge fan of Breaking Bad, enjoyed my time playing the game and look forward to seeing it develop. My review will be updated as and when this game is updated.

+Awesome pixel-art style
+Simple building mechanics, similar to XCOM or Smooth Operators
+Four different types of drugs which can be produced using science, b**ch!
+You can order your employees to attack the other businesses in the area and take control of them, you are the one who knocks
+Your products are automatically collected from your base of operations to be delivered to your distributors
+Taking over other facilities gets gradually more difficult as you get further away from your base of operations
+The devs have set up a trello board so you can track their progress and they seem to be pretty active on the Steam forums, they're also very friendly
+Good AI
+Character descriptions are rather amusing
+Nice soundtrack
+Randomly generated cities

-As mentioned there's not much to it, I won't mention everything and most of it can be discounted since it's Early Access but the main things are there's no tutorial so you have to learn for yourself and there's no objective other than make money
-No way of speeding up time

Verdict:
8

An interesting strategy game with an awesome art style, simple mechanics and a good variety of products that is somewhat let down by its lack of content. If you're a fan of Breaking Bad this is not one to miss out on.

***This review was written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ah! Nothing like waking up to the aroma of meth cooking in the morning!

The Good Fun. Hiding from cops while cooking up all sorts of nefarious product in underground labs is delightfully entertaining
Straightforward UI. There's no tutorial (or at least not one that I found), but its pretty easy to just sit down and GO.
Graphics / Artwork. It feels a bit dodgy and run down, almost like graffiti art people, which is appropriate considering the subject matter.
The minion AI isn't stupid. For the most part, it does precisely what it should be doing at a particular moment.
Creepy music that I think works for a game like this

The Bad No save-game? Seriously? I realize that they're probably trying to prevent players from saving before raids and then loading if they fail, but what if I have conquered the sandbox and want to play again, but don't want to throw away my awesome conquest?
Super easy. I was able to beat it pretty-much the first time I picked it up. The strategy is very straightforward. If you don't have a line of junkies spilling out onto the street, and nobody dies, the police don't show up. Its all about managing that flow. Once its managed, the game becomes simple, and you can start training your conquest armies in peace.
Overflowing money. Towards the endgame, you have too much money and nothing to buy. Part of this is because the money-stashes only hold $1000. When I beat the sandbox, there were whole houses that were nothing but money stashes because the game nags at you irritatingly every time you get money but have nowhere to put it.
I am playing this during early access, so take these with a grain of salt, but there are some bugs. The delivery trucks didn't work for me. They would get to a place and stop and then never move again. The controls are also a bit finnicky when it comes to assigning workers to rooms.

Suggestions Guns would be good. Considering the subject matter, I don't think devs need to worry about violence influencing children
Competing drug labs would also be good. It might be fun to try and get the cops to go after them, as well as bust up their operations yourself
There's no real difference in the drugs aside from market value. I would have liked some kind of tangential side effect, like Acid-takers tripping out and becoming erratic, pot smokers becoming mellow, speed users getting into more fights (etc)
I think it would also be more fun if there were a bonus to providing a selection of substances, rather than really just wanting to provide the most expensive one.

ConclusionGood game already. I have high hopes for the final product being even better!  :)

I've had a lot of fun with this game over the last two days, probably because it reminds me of work that I've done for major corporations in the retail and fast food industries - the only difference being that this game doesn't leave me feeling all guilty and dirty afterwards :P

In all seriousness though, this game is worth buying if you like tycoon style games and you're not offended by the theme (it is just a game after all). The game has a nice art style and atmosphere, and the mechanics work pretty well for something that is still very early access. It already has that tycoon game satisfaction of starting with a small basement with limited facilities and gradually working your way up until you have basically taken over the whole town with enough money and hired muscle to be an unstopable force.

You can get through a single game fairly quickly, but it's still fun to replay the sandbox level as it is slightly different every time you play it with some procedural generation of the map.

It is early access and that means the game still lacks content. Nothing jumps out as being missing but there also isn't that much there. It's already fun though and it can only get better as the game continues to develop.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An interesting take on business simulators; This is a local drug ring simulator where you start off with a small shop, growing weed and selling it to junkies and whatnot.

From your income you can upgrade your rooms, build new ones, start digging underground for a larger basement (which means more room for rooms), hire people to grow or mix your drugs, sell or transport said drugs, or keep your people safe from angry addicts and police raids. Or you could send them out to other buildings and expand your business through some...aggressive negotiations...

The game looks really nice and I think the choice for low resolution graphics has payed off in this case. There isn't much in terms of guiding new players into the game, and it feels more like a sandbox, but there is a sound foundation for what can become a great game, regardless of what anybody may think about drugs.

I actually feel inclined to writing a beginners guide, but the game IS actually really easy to pick up, as long as you don't fear losing the first few games figuring it out.

Definately has potential.

Time to cook.

If you ever wondered what it's like to play a drug lord simulator, this is it. The game plays like a strategy game, therefore demands critical thinking and micromanagement. If you aren't any good at strategy games, I would still recommend you give it a shot. This is coming from a player who doesn't play any strategy games.

The game is still in development and has yet to reach it's full potential. At the moment I don't think there is enough replay capability to justify spending the 8 or 9 dollars.

If you do decide to pick this up now, my advice is to jump right into it. Trial by fire. Your first several attempts are going to be, more often than not, colossal failures. The game currently has no tips or suggestions for noobs. It actually reminded me of my first time playing Minecraft in that there were no clear instructions. But with a little perserverance, you will understand the innerworkings of the game.

Final thoughts: Put this game on your wishlist and keep an eye on it. I believe once this game rolls out more content and adresses its lack of replayability, it will find a nice place in both your heart and library.

And remember, don't do drugs kids.

The labor costs and hiring fee then become so expensive that its almost impossible to get out of the hole. Other than that its a fun game, you have to create a drug empire from your basement.


THE TIP IS WAY OUT OF DATE (Early Release in May 2015)

A tip that might help you finnish the game like I did is to start bribing the cops once you have reached a steady income of money. Its almost always going to be worth more later to pay up then having to wait and buy new guards. The only time you should use guards is to attack new buildings. When attacking always make sure you have 1 or 2 extra guards to make sure they can get the job done. If you want to see a nice layout of your first base that can really help you later check my profile. It's in my opinion the most efficient layout that you can have. Always remember to start of with pot first don't jump to crack until you have tons of money to support the attack and support the bribes needed to keep the building. Review targeted for v0.3.0 - Recommended

Positives and negetives

+ level system
+ buildings
+ animation
- 1 game experience ruining glitch
- Repetitive

The level system in the game has improved the game and made it a great experience for the player insted of repetitive gameplay as it was before. since i last played the security rooms were a room and are no longer, i think this is a great evolution towards the game and now a training room that levels up your characters health and strengh (attack damage).

The lockers and upgrades are a great experience to the game to increase the difficulty and make it easier in simple ways.

Simple animations in Basement that give the game a more realistic feel, such as the customers becoming un patient and sometimes ending up dead with an interesting animation that makes the customers have a seizure then dying insted of a sudden death.

There will always be bugs in every beta / alpha but one stood out and made my experience repetitive. when my dealers automatically sit down and rest they sometimes dont register as working in that zone and people are coming into the shop getting angry and beating up all my workers when they are working in the designated zone.

Overall this game was a great enjoyment and will go far in the gaming industry. 7/10

I will continue to review this game after every 0.1.0 updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[Note: This is one of those times when a 'maybe' button would be useful - see explanation at the bottom in regards to the negative review.]

Basement is, in a nutshell, a reversed Sim Tower meets Breaking Bad. As of the current release, you play an unnamed scientist with the aim of bringing the entire city/urban area/whatever it is under your control. The game is bare bones right now, and goes something like this:

- Build new drug labs/security checkpoints.
- Hire new chemists/henchmen.
- Send henchmen to neighboring buildings to take them over: be prepared to send two or three truckloads, as they tend to die in rather short order.
- Send henchmen back to previously conquered locations to fight off police raids (or bribe them if you're making money hand over fist)
- Take over every building on the map; you win!

The game is lacking in content at the moment - my playtime represents a single game start to finish, with the only replay value being in the randomly generated maps. You have a very small selection of room choices and no upgrades or real variety for your chemists and henchmen (beyond very small stat changes that are tied in to the hiring cost/upkeep of them). On the plus side, the developers seem on the ball with patches and rolling out content, so this should be remedied sooner rather than later.

However, I can't recommend it at this time - I think more than a few people would be disappointed by the lack of content for the price. If you want to support the developers, buy it, play it for a bit, and shelve it until you start seeing updates. If you're on the fence, or just know that you'd rather purchase it in a more complete state - just put it on your wishlist and come back in three months.

I did not really have high hopes for this game. I was extremely surprised by Basement. I love the game play, so simple it is perfect. I am looking at you Europa Universalis. I enjoy the fact that when I higher employees, I can see a mini bio of their life. Also, the deep thumping music even solidifies the fact that you are making drugs and there is always a threat of cops catching you. I was presently surprised when I saw I could change screen resolution, sound volume, and music volume in the same menu. Some of the Early Access games I have played do not have these settings, or they are buried in pages after pages of settings. The fact that you can bribe cops helps a massive ton early in the game. All of this being said, I found the game extremely easy. I beat the game the first time after about an hour.  I could just spam guards to protect my starting area. I wish there were more difficulty settings. I would like to see a game mode where you have to fight the cops and another drug manufacturer.  Also, some of the buildings I have taken over from the cops, cannot have a basement to expand the building. Some of the buildings that do have basements cannot be expanded because, there are empty rooms with brick walls that cannot be used for anything.

Pros:
Simple game play
Employee bios
Koolio Music
Video, sound, and music settings
Bribing cops

Cons:
Extremely easy
Only one difficulty
Some buildings cannot be expanded
Brick walled rooms cannot be used

Something that would make this larger map more interesting is more frequent police raids when you have more power & more types of drug manufacturing.

My honest opinion is that this is a must-have game. Whether you're a hardcore gamer or a casual gamer, you'll have amazing experiences with this game! :)

I did not really have high hopes for this game. I was extremely surprised by Basement. I love the game play, so simple it is perfect. I am looking at you Europa Universalis. I enjoy the fact that when I higher employees, I can see a mini bio of their life. Also, the deep thumping music even solidifies the fact that you are making drugs and there is always a threat of cops catching you. I was presently surprised when I saw I could change screen resolution, sound volume, and music volume in the same menu. Some of the Early Access games I have played do not have these settings, or they are buried in pages after pages of settings. The fact that you can bribe cops helps a massive ton early in the game. All of this being said, I found the game extremely easy. I beat the game the first time after about an hour.  I could just spam guards to protect my starting area. I wish there were more difficulty settings. I would like to see a game mode where you have to fight the cops and another drug manufacturer.  Also, some of the buildings I have taken over from the cops, cannot have a basement to expand the building. Some of the buildings that do have basements cannot be expanded because, there are empty rooms with brick walls that cannot be used for anything.

Pros:
Simple game play
Employee bios
Koolio Music
Video, sound, and music settings
Bribing cops

Cons:
Extremely easy
Only one difficulty
Some buildings cannot be expanded
Brick walled rooms cannot be used

What can I say? This game is amazing. It isn't perfect, but most games aren't. This game is for you if you love tycoon games and selling drugs to random homeless men and women, which actually kind of makes the game sound boring, but believe me it isn't. I give this game an 8/10 and here is why:


Pros:

-The game simply has an amazing concept which I enjoy and find sometimes comedic which is to sell drugs. Simple, but I love that about it. It isn't complicated and takes almost no time to get a hang of, but I love it.

-Good looking game. It has good graphics and I do understand it is a pixel game but it just looks nice. It is appealing to the eye which makes it easier to binge on for a few hours.

-Still being updated. They update the game and I only got the game today but to my understanding they update it either often or in big updates at a time, since the game is rather new and has still changed a lot since it came out. I finished the game and I cant wait to play it again when they add new exciting things to do.

-Casual. It isn't a very difficult game to play and is kind of relaxing when you get into it... Well as relaxing as a drug cooking and dealing game can be...

-Replayability. It is decently replayable. I am not going to replay the game 50 more times and waste 100 hours of my life on it (at least not until they update it again) but still decently replayable.


Cons

-Repetative. Even though it is replayable, after a few run throughs, I'd imagine that it would become very repetative, which is why I hope they continue to update the game.

-Short. It does not take very long to beat the game especially if you tried. I kind of messed around a bit and still beat the game in less then 2 hours. If I really tried I could do it in less then 1.5 hours.

-Easy. Yes I did say it was casual but I really hope they add maybe a difficulty option or some way to make it more of a challenge after beating the game the first time. I beat it once and now I want to beat it again, but I want it to be harder then the first time and give me a good run for my money.

-No content. It is in early access which is why there is less content then a full fledged game would and should have but it is also most likely cheaper then the game will be in the future and is almost an investment in a game in hopes it will become even better.


Overall, great game. It needs some work but it is early access so don't get it and immediatelly refund it because wait a week or two and they will already have some new stuff to try out. I actually found out about this game from a youtube video by Sips and I decided to get the game. If you are uncomfortable getting an early access game then don't. If you are unsure remember that you will be getting an unfinished game but you will also be supporting the developers and speeding up progress at the same time. I hope everyone who gets the game enjoys it like I did and it now eagerly waiting for the next update.

Edited review.

Basement is a fun management game that puts you in the shoes of a drug dealer attempting to expand his empire in an urban setting.

Although still in Early Access, it is fairly playable in its current state, with each subsequent update seemingly focused on extending the game's already considerable playability further.

The game requires you to acquire buildings to setup your operations and hire staff to manufacture and distribute your product (as well as hiring muscle to protect it).

In addition, you must keep up with the demand of junkies, while diversifying in what drugs you make/sell. This increases your revenue, enabling you to acquire new buildings and expand your empire further, but also makes your business more prone to police raids.

Buying transport to transport goods between premises is an option provided you have a garage, providing further depth to your manufacturing and distribution network, and forcing you to think about designating premises to perform particular functions: manufacture, distribution, storage etc.

Each character in the game has a set of stats which indicates things attributes such as: health, damage, ability to sell drugs, ability to manufacture etc. which level up over time as the attribute is used. This enables you to specialise your employees in order to maximise their effectiveness at their given tasks.

Aesthetically the game's pixel graphics are well-done and quite charming in their presentation.
The minimal soundtrack compliments the atmosphere and immersion the chosen pixel art style affords, and I look forward to future updates that expand out the content even further.

At the moment the game is currently only a sandbox mode, but the developer has mentioned future updates will also include other traditional game modes.

Should you buy the game now in its current state, you will get something that is currently playable, but will also be contributing to its further enhancement which is en exciting prospect given how fun it already is.

Lets just hope the updates keep coming :)
